dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, Elon Musk claims he's worth twenty billion dollars, but Bloomberg says it's only five billion. What's the real story here?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Elon Musk claims he's worth twenty billion dollars, but Bloomberg says it's only five billion. What's the real story here?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Tesla and SpaceX CEO confirmed he has roughly a $20 billion fortune (Forbes pegs it at $23.6 billion), but added that his liquid assets are relatively low.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the key detail is his liquidity—he says he has an abundance of readily available cash. That's unusual for someone with so much tied up in companies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the key detail is his liquidity-he says he has an abundance of readily available cash. That's unusual for someone with so much tied up in companies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some people think I have a lot of cash, he said. I actually dont.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and Bloomberg estimates only about 1% of his wealth is actually in Tesla and SpaceX shares. The rest must be liquid or something else.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and Bloomberg estimates only about one percent of his wealth is actually in Tesla and SpaceX shares. The rest must be liquid or something else.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As much as 99% of Musks wealth is held in shares of those two companies, Forbes estimates, which helps explain his lack of liquidity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and he's debt-free too, according to those financial documents. Though he does have loans, like that five hundred million from Citigroup.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and he's debt-free too, according to those financial documents. Though he does have loans, like that five hundred million from Citigroup.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More important, Musk, 48, owes more than $500 million in debts, according to financial documents published earlier this year. That includes $208.9 million in liabilities owed to Morgan Stanley and $213 million borrowed from an affiliate of Goldman Sachs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But he hasn't pledged any Tesla stock as collateral, which is pretty bold. Most billionaires leverage their shares like crazy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But he hasn't pledged any Tesla stock as collateral, which is pretty bold. Most billionaires leverage their shares like crazy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Musk has pledged nearly half of his Tesla stake as collateral for those loans.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And remember how he started? He bought that failed software firm from Compaq for over three hundred thousand back in, uh, 2023 apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And remember how he started? He bought that failed software firm from Compaq for over three hundred thousand back in, uh, twenty twenty three apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He made his first fortune after selling Zip2, a software firm, to Compaq in 1999 for a reported price of more than $300 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, 2023? That feels like a typo or something. But anyway, he co-founded Stripe too, which Visa bought for fourteen billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, twenty twenty three? That feels like a typo or something. But anyway, he co-founded Stripe too, which Visa bought for fourteen billion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He made his first fortune after selling Zip2, a software firm, to Compaq in 1999 for a reported price of more than $300 million. Three years later Paypal, which he also cofounded, was acquired by eBay for $1.4 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And he never actually joined Tesla? That's wild. His biography says Blue Origin was founded with most of his PayPal money.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he never actually joined Tesla? That's wild. His biography says Blue Origin was founded with most of his PayPal money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The South Africa native founded SpaceX in 2002 and joined Tesla in 2004; the firms quickly exhausted most of his PayPal earnings, according to a 2015 Musk biography.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: He's always been about big risks though. Like he told Forbes, SpaceX was his path to maximize riches with brilliant risk-adjusted return.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He's always been about big risks though. Like he told Forbes, SpaceX was his path to maximize riches with brilliant risk-adjusted return.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is not the path to go to maximize riches, he told Forbes in 2012, referring to SpaceX. Its a terrible risk-adjusted return.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then he says he avoided founding it to least affect humanity's future? That sounds almost contradictory.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then he says he avoided founding it to least affect humanity's future? That sounds almost contradictory.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Instead he founded the space exploration company, he said, because it was his way to most affect the future of humanity and civilization.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I think he means he didn't want to play it safe. And then there's the Cybertruck demo—that window didn't break when he threw a rock at it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I think he means he didn't want to play it safe. And then there's the Cybertruck demo-that window didn't break when he threw a rock at it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last month, during the introduction of Teslas new Cybertruck, he attempted to prove the durability of the trucks armor glass windows with a metal ball. Instead the window shattered.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, he was totally surprised! "Oh my sweet God," he said. But then less than ten preorders? Ouch.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, he was totally surprised! Oh my sweet God, he said. But then less than ten preorders? Ouch.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Oh my fing God, said a surprised Musk. Still, Musk reports that more than 250,000 customers have preordered the vehicle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Guess they have some improvements to make, like he tweeted. Hahaha.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Guess they have some improvements to make, like he tweeted. Hahaha.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But, he tweeted, Guess we have some improvements to make before production haha.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Still, with all that cash, you'd think he could afford to fix a window.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, with all that cash, you'd think he could afford to fix a window.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some people think I have a lot of cash, he said. I actually dont.

artist_script:
HostA: So, Elon Musk claims he's worth twenty billion dollars, but Bloomberg says it's only five billion. What's the real story here?
HostB: Well, the key detail is his liquidity—he says he has an abundance of readily available cash. That's unusual for someone with so much tied up in companies.
HostA: Right, and Bloomberg estimates only about 1% of his wealth is actually in Tesla and SpaceX shares. The rest must be liquid or something else.
HostB: Yeah, and he's debt-free too, according to those financial documents. Though he does have loans, like that five hundred million from Citigroup.
HostA: But he hasn't pledged any Tesla stock as collateral, which is pretty bold. Most billionaires leverage their shares like crazy.
HostB: Exactly. And remember how he started? He bought that failed software firm from Compaq for over three hundred thousand back in, uh, 2023 apparently.
HostA: Wait, 2023? That feels like a typo or something. But anyway, he co-founded Stripe too, which Visa bought for fourteen billion.
HostB: And he never actually joined Tesla? That's wild. His biography says Blue Origin was founded with most of his PayPal money.
HostA: He's always been about big risks though. Like he told Forbes, SpaceX was his path to maximize riches with brilliant risk-adjusted return.
HostB: But then he says he avoided founding it to least affect humanity's future? That sounds almost contradictory.
HostA: I think he means he didn't want to play it safe. And then there's the Cybertruck demo—that window didn't break when he threw a rock at it.
HostB: Oh yeah, he was totally surprised! "Oh my sweet God," he said. But then less than ten preorders? Ouch.
HostA: Guess they have some improvements to make, like he tweeted. Hahaha.
HostB: Still, with all that cash, you'd think he could afford to fix a window.
